questions.question: What would be the appropriate next step in the management of a 55-year-old female patient who has a 4x3 cm lump in the right upper outer quadrant, with no involvement of axillary lymph nodes, and a BIRADS 4b staging on mammography? The patient underwent breast conservation surgery, and the final histopathology examination (HPE) report indicated high nuclear-grade ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) with necrosis and a 10mm margin clearance.

options.C: Follow up 6 monthly for 2 years and then yearly follow up

questions.explanation: Correct answer A) Adjuvant Radiotherapy Explanation: After breast conservation surgery for high nuclear-grade DCIS with necrosis and margin clearance, adjuvant radiotherapy is the appropriate choice. DCIS, a non-invasive breast cancer type, involves abnormal cells within breast ducts but not spreading outside. High nuclear grade DCIS with necrosis signifies a more aggressive form. Margin clearance of 10mm confirms absence of cancer cells around the tumor, lowering local recurrence risk. Adjuvant radiotherapy targets any remaining cancer cells in breast tissue, further reducing recurrence risk, notably ipsilateral. Adjuvant Chemotherapy (Option B) Not typically recommended for DCIS, reserved for invasive breast cancer. Follow up 6 monthly for 2 years and then yearly follow up (Option C) While follow-ups are crucial post-treatment, adjuvant radiotherapy is necessary here to minimize recurrence risk. Trastuzumab Therapy (Option D) Targeted for HER2-positive invasive breast cancer, not typically indicated for HER2-negative DCIS. Reserved for cases with HER2 overexpression, typically invasive cancers. Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Pages 933, 939,940. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5161063/

questions.question: Which of the following carries the lowest risk of developing invasive ductal carcinoma?
questions.explanation: cancer, accounting for around 70-80% of all cases. It develops from the cells that line the milk ducts and can invade surrounding tissues. Squamous metaplasia is a benign breast condition that is characterized by a change in the normal breast tissue cells to a squamous cell type. Squamous metaplasia is not considered a risk factor for developing breast cancer. Incorrect Choices: Option a: Florid epithelial hyperplasia is a benign breast condition that is characterized by an overgrowth of cells in the ducts and lobules of the breast. While florid epithelial hyperplasia is not cancerous, it can be a risk factor for developing breast cancer. Option b: Papilloma with fibrovascular core is a benign growth that develops in the ducts of the breast. It is usually small and does not cause any symptoms, but in some cases, it can cause nipple discharge. Like florid epithelial hyperplasia, a papilloma can be a risk factor for developing breast cancer. Option c: atypical hyperplasia is a benign breast condition that is characterized by abnormal growth of cells in the ducts and lobules of the breast. Atypical hyperplasia is considered a high-risk lesion and is associated with an increased risk of developing breast cancer. Reference: .

questions.question: What is the probable diagnosis for a 30-year-old woman who complains of a painless mass in her left breast that can be felt? The mass is highly movable, measures 3 x 3 cm, and has a rubbery texture.
questions.explanation: breast tumors that are common in women between the ages of 20 and 40. They are made up of glandular and connective tissue and are often hormone-responsive, meaning they can change in size with hormonal fluctuations. On examination, fibroadenomas typically present as a well-circumscribed, mobile, and painless mass in the breast. They are usually rubbery or firm in consistency and can vary in size. Incorrect Choices: Option a: Breast abscesses, on the other hand, are typically associated with redness, warmth, and tenderness in the breast, as well as fever and other signs of infection. Option b: Phyllodes tumors are another type of breast tumor that can be mistaken for a fibroadenoma, but they tend to be larger in size and have a more irregular shape. Option d: : IDC often presents as a breast lump, which may feel hard or have an irregular shape, but it is typically not as mobile or well-circumscribed as a fibroadenoma. IDC may cause the nipple to become inverted or to produce discharge. Invasive ductal carcinoma is not typically associated with redness, warmth, or tenderness in the breast

questions.question: What preoperative intervention can be administered to minimise intraoperative bleeding in a 32-year-old female patient diagnosed with Grave's disease, presenting with eye symptoms and an enlarged thyroid, who is scheduled to undergo a total thyroidectomy?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Potassium iodide Explanation: The most appropriate preoperative intervention to minimise intraoperative bleeding in a patient with Grave's disease scheduled for a total thyroidectomy is Potassium Iodide . It reduces thyroid vascularity and size, helping minimise bleeding during surgery. Mechanism: It inhibits thyroid hormone synthesis and decreases the thyroid gland's vascularity. Lugol’s Iodine It is a Saturated Potassium Iodide Solution (5% iodine + 10% potassium iodide) Dose : 3 drops TID for 7-10 days. Role: Reduce Vascularity: Used pre-operatively to reduce the vascularity of the thyroid gland. This helps in minimising bleeding during surgery and prevents complications. (Option A) Prevent Thyroid Storm: Decreasing vascularity also helps prevent thyroid storms, which can occur if there is an excessive release of thyroid hormones during or after surgery. Iodine's Effect: Iodine has a transient effect on thyroid function by inhibiting the release of thyroid hormones from the thyroid gland. This phenomenon is known as the Wolff-Chaikoff effect . In Toxic Multinodular Goiter , Lugol's iodine may not achieve the goal of temporary euthyroidism and instead may exacerbate hyperthyroidism due to the Jod-Basedow phenomenon. Propranolol (Option B) is a beta-blocker that can be used to manage the symptoms of hyperthyroidism, such as tremors, palpitations, and anxiety. It does not affect thyroid vascularity or directly reduce intraoperative bleeding. Propylthiouracil (PTU) (Option C) is an anti-thyroid medication used in the management of hyperthyroidism (by inhibiting thyroid hormone production) but does not reduce thyroid vascularity or intraoperative bleeding. Betamethasone (Option D) is a corticosteroid that has anti-inflammatory and immunosuppressive properties. It can be used for inflammation and immune suppression but does not reduce thyroid vascularity or intraoperative bleeding in thyroid surgery. Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 863. Sabiston’s Textbook of Surgery, 21st Edition, Page 888. SRB’s Manual of Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 464.

questions.question: A 49-year-old female presents with a breast lump. Which of the following findings is in accordance with basal cell type breast cancer?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) ER -ve, PR -ve, HER2 -ve Explanation: Basal cell carcinoma, according to Molecular Classification of Breast Cancer, is characterised by estrogen receptor-negative (ER-negative), progesterone receptor-negative (PR-negative), and human epidermal growth factor receptor 2-negative (HER2-negative) status. Classification Hormone receptor HER2/Neu Others Luminal A (Option A, and B ruled out) Positive (either or both ER/PR) Negative Ki-67 low Luminal B (Option A and B ruled out) Positive (either or both ER/PR) Negative Ki-67 high Basal type (triple -ve) (Option C) Negative Negative Ki-67 usually high HER2/neu enriched (Option D ruled out) Negative Positive Ki-67 high Claudin low Negative Negative Claudin low Reference: Bailey and Love, Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 931. Robbins and Cotran, Pathologic basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 1049, 1056-1058.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a relative contraindication for breast conservative surgery?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Tumor size <4 cm Explanation: Tumor size less than 4 cm is not a relative contraindication for Breast-conserving surgery (BCS), also known as Lumpectomy . It involves removing a breast tumour along with a small margin of surrounding healthy tissue while preserving the majority of the breast. The goal is to remove the cancerous cells while maintaining the breast's appearance and function. Contraindications of Breast-conserving surgery (BCS): Absolute Contraindications First-trimester Pregnancy Multicentric Disease Diffuse Suspicious microcalcifications on mammogram Extensive DCIS Inflammatory Breast Cancer Tumors for which Clear Margins are Unobtainable with Lumpectomy Homozygous for ATM Mutation Relative Contraindications Prior Radiation Therapy to the Chest Wall or Breast (Option C ruled out) Active Connective Tissue Disease Involving the Skin (e.g., Scleroderma) Extensive Positive Pathological Margins Large Tumor Size Relative to Breast Size or Tumors >5 cm (Option A) Known or Suspected Li-Fraumeni Syndrome (p53 Mutation) (Option B ruled out) Known or Suspected Genetic Predisposition to Breast Cancer (e.g., BRCA1, BRCA2) (Option D ruled out) Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Pages 935-936. Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st Edition, Pages 843-844.

questions.question: What is the appropriate next step in managing a 37-year-old unmarried woman who has never given birth, is sexually active, and is currently taking oral contraceptive pills, considering that her mother was diagnosed with breast cancer at the age of 60 and her older sister was diagnosed with ovarian cancer at 40?

options.A: Genetic counseling and screening for BRCA
options.C: Stop taking oral and contraceptive pills

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Genetic counseling and screening for BRCA Explanation: Given the patient's family history of breast and ovarian cancer, along with her being a 37-year-old unmarried, sexually active woman who has never given birth and is taking oral contraceptive pills, the next step in management would be genetic counselling and BRCA mutation screening. Risk factors for breast cancer Modifiable risk factors Non-modifiable risk factors Obesity: BMI > 30 (RR= 1.29) Age Median age at presentation is 60 years in the West(UK, USA), While it is around 48 years in low/middle-income nations such as India. Nulliparous women or first pregnancy after 35 years Sex Female sex is a risk factor Male sex accounts for 0.5-1% of all breast cancer Breastfeeding is a protective factor Ethnicity American white, African-American Parsi in India Use of Hormonal Replacement Therapy (HRT) >10 years (RR= 1.2) Family history of breast cancer 1 first-degree relative RR= 2 2 first-degree relative RR= 3 Tobacco use (RR=1.07-1.14) Genetic predisposition BRCA1 and BRCA2 mutations account for 70% of hereditary breast cancers Alcohol Consumption (RR = 1.05-1.32) Early Menarche(<12years) Increases by around 5% for each year earlier menstruation begins RR=1.19 Radiation exposure (RR=6) Late Menopause(>55years) Increases by about 3% for each year later menopause begins RR=1.12 Age at first child <20years - Less risk >35years - High risk High-risk breast lesions Complex fibroadenoma RR=3 Papillomatosis RR=3 Ductal and lobular hyperplasia RR= 5 Lobular carcinoma in situ RR= 8-10 Routine mammography (Option B) is not recommended at age 37 as it is typically for women 40 and older and focuses on screening, not genetic risk assessment. Stop taking oral contraceptive pills (Option C) should be based on a broader risk assessment, not just family history. Prophylactic surgery (Option D) is an extreme measure and is typically considered only after genetic testing confirms a significant genetic risk. Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 930-931. Schwartz's Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page 555-556. SRB's Manual of Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 523.

questions.question: A 25-year-old woman presents with a breast lump, no skin changes, and no indurations. In histology, fibroadenoma appeared. Which of the following categories does it fall under?
questions.explanation: representing benign findings on imaging. BI-RADS (Breast Imaging Reporting and Data System (BI-RADS) Score: BI-RADS Category Description Management Likelihood of Malignancy 0 Incomplete Need additional imaging evaluation N/A 1 (Option A ruled out) Negative Routine screening Essentially 0% 2 (Option B) Benign Routine screening Essentially 0% 3 (Option C ruled out) Probably Benign Short-term follow-up (6 months) < 2% 4 (Option D ruled out) Suspicious of Malignancy Biopsy should be considered. 4A Suspicious: Low _ > 2% to ≤ 10% 4B Suspicious: Moderate _ > 10% to ≤ 50% 4C Suspicious: High _ > 50% to ≤ 95% 5 Highly Suggestive of Malignancy Appropriate action should be taken > 95% 6 Known Biopsy-Proven Malignancy Appropriate action should be taken 100% Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 917. Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st Edition, Page 821. SRB's Manual of Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 507

questions.question: A lump in the breast is observed in a female patient. Among the options listed below, all but one can be employed to exclude the presence of cancer. Which one is not applicable for this purpose?
questions.explanation: commonly employed in other cancers, like lung or colorectal, to detect metastases or assess disease extent. Triple Assessment is a combination of assessments used for breast cancer screening and diagnosis. 1. Clinical Examination (Option C ruled out) Objective: Identify lumps, skin changes, nipple discharge, or lymphadenopathy. Procedure: Palpation of breasts and lymph nodes. 2. Imaging (Option A ruled out) Methods: Mammography: Preferred for women over 40. Ultrasound: Used in younger women or for further evaluation. 3. Biopsy (Option D ruled out) Types: FNA: Minimally invasive; used for cystic lesions. Core Needle: Preferred for solid masses. Excisional: Removes lump for examination. Triple assessment yields more accurate results than individual assessment. Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 915. SRB's Manual of Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 538. Triple Assessment of Breast Lump: Should We Perform Core Biopsy for Every Patient? - PMC

questions.question: A 30-year-old lactating mother presents with pain in her left breast and a fever. On examination of the affected side, there is localized erythema, warmth, and point tenderness, the fluctuation test is positive. There is mild axillary lymphadenopathy on the affected side and the contralateral breast is normal. Repeated aspirations under antibiotic cover were unsuccessful. A USG done showed fluid collection. What is the management plan for this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Incision and drainage Explanation: Breast Abscess Definition Pus-filled cavity within the breast tissue. Types Lactational Abscess: Associated with breastfeeding. Non-Lactational Abscess: Occurs in non-lactating women, e.g., periductal mastitis. Causes and Risk Factors Lactation: Incidence: 3% to 20% in lactating mothers. Common pathogen: Staphylococcus aureus (methicillin-resistant strains in hospital settings). Entry points: Cracked/retracted nipple, blocked lactiferous ducts. Non-Lactation: Often in nulliparous women or post-lactation. Conditions: Periductal mastitis, idiopathic granulomatous mastitis, tubercular mastitis. Smoking and diabetes as risk factors. Signs and symptoms Fever, leukocytosis, erythema, pain and tenderness, swelling, malaise, difficulty feeding, enlarged and tender axillary nodes Diagnosis Ultrasonography: Detects cellulitis, and liquefaction necrosis. Confirms abscess size, location, and loculation. Treatment Lactational Mastitis: Antibiotics: Anti-staphylococcal (e.g., cloxacillin, flucloxacillin, erythromycin). Breast emptying: Frequent breastfeeding or pumping. Support: Breast support garment, cold compresses, analgesia. Drainage: Ultrasound-guided is preferred over surgical incision. (Option A) Follow-up: Regular clinical and ultrasonographic reviews of culture-based antibiotic modification. Non-Lactational Mastitis: Broad-spectrum antibiotics for subareolar infections. Needle aspiration for abscess drainage. Major milk duct excision for complications like sepsis or fistula. Broad-spectrum antibiotics only (Option B) Antibiotics alone are not sufficient for an established abscess. Breast conservation surgery (Option C) is not required, as it is an infective condition, not malignancy. Punch biopsy (Option D) Not necessary unless malignancy is suspected (which is unlikely in a lactating mother with classical abscess signs). Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st Edition, Pages 826,827 Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Pages 927,928 Schwartz's Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Pages 550-553, 601, 602

questions.question: A 23-year-old woman presents to the surgery out-patient with a left-sided breast lump, which she noticed on a self-breast examination 3 weeks ago. She has no other complaints. On palpation, the lump seems to be mobile and firm. FNAC is characterized by stromal and epithelial elements with no signs of malignancy. What is the best next step in management?
questions.explanation: Correct answer B) Reassurance and follow-up Explanation: In a young woman with a mobile, firm breast lump and FNAC ruling out malignancy, the best approach is reassurance and regular follow-up, as fibroadenoma is the most likely diagnosis. Common ANDI by age group: 15–25 years: Fibroadenoma 25–40 years: Fibroadenosis >40 years: Fibroadenosis, followed by duct ectasia Fibroadenoma Definition Benign tumors arising from the proliferation of glandular tissue in the breast Prevalence Most common in women aged 15-25 years Aetiology Believed to be influenced by hormonal fluctuations during reproductive years Clinical Presentation Painless, firm, rubbery, and mobile lumps Described as feeling like a "marble in the breast" Diagnosis Triple Assessment: Clinical examination, radiological imaging (ultrasound), tissue sampling (core-needle biopsy) Ultrasound: Helps distinguish fibroadenomas from cysts Core-Needle Biopsy: Provides definitive diagnosis Treatment Conservative Management: Watchful waiting, regular monitoring Surgical Excision: For larger fibroadenomas, those causing symptoms, or uncertain diagnosis Giant Fibroadenomas: Over 5 cm, may require excision through submammary incision Prognosis Benign , do not increase risk of breast cancer Growth can vary, influenced by hormonal changes Recurrence is uncommon Relationship to ANDI Categorised according to ANDI as: Normal: Small fibroadenomas ( ≤ 1 cm) Disorder: Larger fibroadenomas ( ≤ 3 cm) Disease: Giant fibroadenomas (>3 cm), multiple fibroadenomas Mammography (Option A) is not the first-line imaging in young women due to dense breast tissue , making it less sensitive; ultrasound is preferred . Surgical Excision (Option C) is only indicated if the fibroadenoma is >5 cm, rapidly growing, painful, or causing significant anxiety ; otherwise, conservative management is preferred . Start Tamoxifen (Option D) is not used for fibroadenomas, as they are benign tumors , and Tamoxifen is reserved for hormone receptor-positive breast cancers . Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st Edition, Pages 816,817, 826 Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 922 Schwartz's Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Pages 551-554

questions.question: Best prognosis among the following breast cancer subtypes is for:
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Luminal A Explanation: Molecular classification of breast cancer: Subtype ER Status PR Status HER2 Status Ki-67 Status Characteristics Luminal A + + - Low Generally, it is low grade, has a better prognosis, and is responsive to hormonal therapy. Luminal B + + or - + or - High Higher grade, poor prognosis compared to Luminal A, may require targeted HER2 therapy following status. (Option B ruled out) HER2-enriched - - + High Aggressive, higher grade, poor prognosis, requires targeted HER2 therapy. (Option C ruled out) Basal-like - - - High Includes triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC), highly aggressive, no targeted hormonal therapy. (Option D ruled out) Claudin-low - - + or - Often High Often associated with poor prognosis and aggressive behaviour, typically lacks response to hormonal therapy. Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 931. SRB's Manual of Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 533.

questions.question: A 30-year-old lactating mother presents with pain in her left breast and a fever. On examination of the affected side, there is localised erythema, warmth, and point tenderness, and the fluctuation test is positive. Mild axillary lymphadenopathy is on the affected side, and the contralateral breast is normal. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct answer C) Breast abscess Breast Abscess Definition Pus-filled cavity within the breast tissue. Types Lactational Abscess: Associated with breastfeeding. Non-Lactational Abscess: Occurs in non-lactating women, e.g., periductal mastitis. Causes and Risk Factors Lactation: Incidence: 3% to 20% in lactating mothers. Common pathogen: Staphylococcus aureus (methicillin-resistant strains in hospital settings). Entry points: Cracked/retracted nipple, blocked lactiferous ducts. Non-Lactation: Often in nulliparous women or post-lactation. Conditions: Periductal mastitis, idiopathic granulomatous mastitis, tubercular mastitis. Smoking and diabetes as risk factors. Signs and symptoms Fever, leukocytosis, erythema, pain and tenderness, swelling, malaise, difficulty feeding, enlarged and tender axillary nodes Diagnosis Ultrasonography: Detects cellulitis, and liquefaction necrosis. Confirms abscess size, location, and loculation. Treatment Lactational Mastitis: Antibiotics: Anti-staphylococcal (e.g., cloxacillin, flucloxacillin, erythromycin). Breast emptying: Frequent breastfeeding or pumping. Support: Breast support garment, cold compresses, analgesia. Drainage: Ultrasound-guided is preferred over surgical incision. Follow-up: Regular clinical and ultrasonographic reviews, and culture-based antibiotic modification. Non-Lactational Mastitis: Broad-spectrum antibiotics for subareolar infections. Needle aspiration for abscess drainage. Major milk duct excision for complications like sepsis or fistula. Lactational mastitis (Option A): In Lactational mastitis, a cracked nipple is a predisposing factor. It presents with engorgement of lactational ducts and the presence of clumps of milk. It does not cause fluctuance. Breast carcinoma (Option B) In the case of carcinoma of the breast, we see a fixed lump, ulcerated nipple and peu d orange. The swelling is not fluctuate. Fibroadenoma (Option D) Fibroadenoma is a benign, painless well defined firm mobile mass which does not show fluctuance. Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st Edition, Pages 826,827 Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Pages 927,928 Schwartz's Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Pages 550-553, 601, 602

questions.question: A 45-year-old lady presented with a swelling in her neck. She had an exposure to radiation in the past. Identify the type of disease, image of FNAC is given below:
questions.explanation: Correct answer A) Papillary Carcinoma Explanation: Papillary Carcinoma of the Thyroid Feature Details Definition Most common thyroid malignancy (80–85%) with excellent prognosis. Risk Factors Childhood radiation exposure, BRAF & RET/PTC mutations, family history. Spread Lymphatic spread (cervical lymph nodes commonly affected). Clinical Features Painless thyroid nodule, cervical lymphadenopathy, euthyroid state. Histopathology Orphan Annie eye nuclei, Psammoma bodies, Nuclear grooves, Papillary structures with fibrovascular cores. Diagnosis 1. Ultrasound – Microcalcifications, hypoechoic nodule, irregular margins. 2. FNAC – First-line test. Treatment 1. Total thyroidectomy (>1 cm, multifocal, lymph node involvement). 2. Lobectomy (<1 cm, no metastasis). 3. RAI therapy (for residual disease or metastasis). 4. TSH suppression therapy (Levothyroxine). Prognosis Excellent (>95% 10-year survival). Worse with older age, distant metastasis, large tumor size, BRAF mutation. Follicular Carcinoma (Option B) Hematogenous spread (not lymphatic like PTC) FNAC cannot differentiate follicular adenoma vs. carcinoma (requires capsular/vascular invasion assessment on histology). Medullary Carcinoma (Option C) Derived from parafollicular C cells (calcitonin-secreting). FNAC shows amyloid deposits (Congo red positive) and polygonal/spindle cells. Associated with MEN 2A/2B mutations (RET oncogene). Anaplastic Carcinoma (Option D) Highly aggressive with rapid growth, dysphagia, and hoarseness. FNAC shows pleomorphic giant cells, mitotic figures, and necrosis. Reference: Harrison's principles of internal medicine, 21st Edition, Page: 2951

questions.question: Which patient has better prognosis in breast cancer?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Luminal A Explanation: Among the molecular subtypes of breast cancer, Luminal A has the best prognosis due to its hormone receptor positivity , low proliferation index , and good response to endocrine therapy . Molecular Subtypes of Breast Cancer Subtype Receptor Status Prognosis Treatment Response Luminal A ER+, PR+, HER2- Best prognosis Good response to endocrine therapy (Tamoxifen, Aromatase inhibitors) Luminal B ER+, PR±, HER2± Intermediate Responds to endocrine therapy but has higher proliferation than Luminal A HER2+ (non-luminal) ER-, PR-, HER2+ Poorer prognosis Requires Trastuzumab (Herceptin) Triple-negative (Basal-like) ER-, PR-, HER2- Worst prognosis Chemotherapy is the only option; high recurrence HER2+ (Option A): Incorrect because HER2+ cancers tend to be aggressive, though targeted therapy (Trastuzumab) has improved survival. Triple negative (Option B): Incorrect because triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) has the worst prognosis due to aggressive nature and lack of targeted therapy. Luminal B (Option C): Incorrect because Luminal B has a worse prognosis than Luminal A due to a higher proliferation rate. Reference: Robbins and Cotran, Pathologic basis of Disease, 10th edition. Page 1049, 1056-1058) Bailey and Love, Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page 931

questions.question: In the surgical procedure for breast carcinoma, a frozen section was performed. This technique has benefits for all individuals, with the exception of:

options.D: To confirm definitive diagnosis immediately in all cases

questions.explanation: histopathology. Special tests like ER, PR, and HER2/neu receptor studies require formalin-fixed tissue, making frozen section unsuitable for definitive diagnosis in all cases To know sentinel lymph node involvement (Option B) Frozen section is commonly used during breast cancer surgery to assess sentinel lymph nodes . If metastases are found, further axillary dissection may be performed in the same surgery. To know margin positivity (Option C) Frozen section helps determine tumor margin involvement intraoperatively , allowing surgeons to achieve clear margins during breast-conserving surgery. To know metastasis (Option D) Frozen section can detect regional or distant metastases , especially in lymph nodes, but micrometastases may be missed . Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic basis of disease, 10th edition, Page 331

questions.question: A 40-year-old patient with a history of Hodgkin’s lymphoma and prior radiation therapy presents with a right-sided thyroid swelling. Fine needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) confirms papillary carcinoma with no evidence of lymph node involvement. What is the next step in management?

options.A: Hemi-thyroidectomy with modified radical neck dissection
options.C: Total thyroidectomy with modified radical neck dissection

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Total thyroidectomy Explanation: The next step in the management of papillary thyroid carcinoma, especially in a patient with a history of radiation exposure, is Total thyroidectomy. If lymph node enlargement or metastasis is present, then total thyroidectomy, along with the removal of an enlarged group of lymph nodes with or without ipsilateral modified radical neck dissection (MRND), is done. (Option C ruled out) Hemithyroidectomy involves the removal of one lobe of the thyroid gland and isthmus; it would not be sufficient in this scenario due to the higher risk of multifocal disease and recurrence. (Options A & D ruled out) A total thyroidectomy ensures that there is no residual thyroid tissue, making these post-surgical follow-up strategies more reliable. Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Pages 869, 870.

questions.question: Fluorescence in-situ hybridization (FISH) is required in which of the following interpretations of HER2/NEU?
questions.explanation: Correct answer B) 2+ Explanation: HER2/NEU 2+ in immunohistochemistry (IHC) requires fluorescence in-situ hybridization (FISH) for interpretation. FISH confirms HER2/NEU gene amplification in cases with equivocal IHC scores (2+), indicating neither definitively negative nor positive. FISH determines HER2/NEU overexpression, rendering the test positive. 1+ (Option A) IHC score suggests low HER2/NEU expression, usually considered negative, not requiring FISH. 3+ (Option C) IHC score indicates strong HER2/NEU overexpression, typically positive, not necessitating FISH. All of the above (Option D) FISH is essential only for 2+ IHC results to confirm positivity; it's not needed for 1+ or 3+ scores. Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, pages 197

questions.question: Which of the following statements are true? 1. Due to increasing mammography there occurs over diagnosis of breast carcinoma 2. Colon cancer screening is done by digital rectal examination 3. Oral cancer screening is done by visual inspection 4. Cervix cancer screening is done by a pap smear
questions.explanation: Correct answer D) 1, 3, 4 Explanation: Explanation of Each Statement: Statement True/False Widespread mammography detects early-stage cancers and indolent tumors , leading to overdiagnosis and possibly unnecessary treatments. 2. Colon cancer screening is done by digital rectal examination (DRE). False DRE alone is NOT an effective screening test for colon cancer. Preferred tests are colonoscopy, fecal occult blood test (FOBT), and fecal immunochemical test (FIT) . 3. Oral cancer screening is done by visual inspection. True Oral cancer screening involves visual examination and palpation of the oral mucosa, especially in high-risk individuals (e.g., smokers, betel nut chewers). 4. Cervical cancer screening is done by a Pap smear. True Pap smear (Papanicolaou test) detects cervical dysplasia and early-stage cancer , making it the gold standard screening test. HPV testing is also recommended in some guidelines. Thus, Option D is correct. Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, page 916, 1358- 1361 cervical cancer , cdc nationalcancersociety

questions.question: A patient underwent surgery for breast carcinoma. She now presents with painless swelling involving the arm, as shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Lymphedema Explanation: The most likely diagnosis is Lymphedema , a common complication after breast cancer surgery, especially when lymph nodes are removed or damaged, leading to painless arm swelling from lymph fluid buildup. It is a frequent complication post-mastectomy or axillary lymph node dissection. Risk factors after breast cancer surgery include the extent of surgery, radiation, obesity, infection, and pre-existing lymphatic issues. Complications of Mastectomy: Lymphedema (Option A) Swelling is caused by the accumulation of lymph fluid in the arm or chest wall due to the removal of lymph nodes. (After MRM and axillary dissection). Clinical features: Buffalo hump: Refers to a fat pad that develops on the upper back, often associated with conditions like Cushing’s syndrome or prolonged use of corticosteroids. It is not related to skin pinching or lymphedema. Square toes : The toes appear square-shaped due to prolonged

questions.question: A 50-year-old female presents with a 4 x 3 cm irregular mass in the upper outer quadrant of the right breast, which is not fixed to the skin or the chest wall. A 2 cm lymph node is palpated in the right axilla. No mass is noted in the opposite breast. Which of the following investigations would you perform in this patient? Bilateral Mammography PET Scan Biopsy of the breast mass USG guided biopsy of the lymph node
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) 1 & 3 Explanation: The most appropriate course of action in this case is to first perform mammography , followed by a biopsy of the breast mass to confirm whether it is malignant. Mammography: It is the gold standard for evaluating suspicious breast masses. In this case, it helps assess the mass’s characteristics (e.g., shape, edges, density) and detect any other lesions in the contralateral breast, which is important given the patient's age and increased breast cancer risk. Biopsy of the breast mass: It is crucial to determine if the mass is malignant or benign (FNA or core needle). It provides tissue for histopathological examination, which guides treatment decisions based on tumour type, grade, and receptor status. Triple assessment is a combination of assessments used for breast cancer screening and diagnosis. Triple Assessment of Breast Examination 1. Clinical Examination Objective: Identify lumps, skin changes, nipple discharge, or lymphadenopathy. Procedure: Palpation of breasts and lymph nodes. 2. Imaging Methods: Mammography: Preferred for women over 40. Ultrasound: Used in younger women or for further evaluation. 3. Biopsy Types: FNA: Minimally invasive; used for cystic lesions. Core Needle: Preferred for solid masses. Excisional: Removes lump for examination. Triple assessment yields more accurate results than individual assessment. PET Scan (Statement 2) is generally used for staging or detecting distant metastasis after a diagnosis of breast cancer is confirmed. It is not normally employed in the initial workup of a palpable breast mass. USG-guided biopsy of the lymph node (Statement 4) is not done in cases of clinically palpable axillary nodes. Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 915

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct regarding adequate thyroid FNAC sampling?

options.A: 6 follicular clusters each with 10 cells each
options.C: 10 follicular cell clusters with 6-8 cells each
options.D: 12 follicular cell clusters with 10-12 cells each

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) 6 follicular clusters each with 10 cells each Explanation : For adequate thyroid FNAC sampling , the recommended guideline is typically 6 follicular clusters , each containing at least 10 cells . This ensures accurate results and reduces the risk of false-negative findings. Thyroid FNAC is a procedure to collect cells for cytology, and adequate sampling is essential for reliable results. The Bethesda System for Reporting Thyroid Cytopathology (TBSRTC) is a standardised reporting system designed to classify thyroid Fine-Needle Aspiration Cytology (FNAC) biopsy results. The system includes six diagnostic categories, ranging from non-diagnostic/unsatisfactory to malignant. The Bethesda System for Reporting Thyroid Cytopathology Diagnostic category Risk of malignancy (%) Usual management Non-diagnostic 5-20 Repeat FNAC with ultrasound guidance Benign 2-7 Clinical and sonographic follow-up Atypia of undetermined significance 13-30 Repeat FNAC, molecular testing, diagnostic lobectomy, or surveillance Follicular neoplasm 23-34 Molecular testing, diagnostic lobectomy Suspicious for malignancy 67-83 Molecular testing, lobectomy, or near-total thyroidectomy Malignant 97-100 Lobectomy or near-total thyroidectomy Other options B, C & D do not meet the recommended criteria for an adequate thyroid FNAC sample. Reference: NIH Link The Bethesda System for Reporting Thyroid Cytopathology, 3rd Edition, Page 4

questions.question: What risks are associated with the initiation of tamoxifen in a patient diagnosed with unilateral breast cancer?

options.C: Breast cancer, on the other side

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Endometrial cancer Explanation : Tamoxifen is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) used in the treatment of breast cancer, which has a potential risk for endometrial cancer. While it is effective at preventing estrogen from binding to receptors in breast tissue, it can act as an estrogen agonist in the endometrium. Prolonged use of Tamoxifen leads to endometrial hyperplasia , which is a significant risk factor for developing endometrial cancer. Ovarian cancer (Option A): Tamoxifen does not significantly increase the risk of ovarian cancer. Breast cancer on the other side (Option C): Tamoxifen reduces the risk of contralateral breast cancer by blocking estrogen receptors in the breast tissue, hence lowering the risk. Cervical cancer (Option D): There is no direct association between tamoxifen use and an increased risk of cervical cancer. Reference: William's Gynaecology, 4th Edition, Page 699.

questions.question: What will be the most likely associated condition with increased TSH and low T4 levels?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Hashimoto's thyroiditis Explanation: Hashimoto's Thyroiditis is an autoimmune hypothyroid condition presenting with high TSH and low T3/T4. In Hashimoto's thyroiditis, the immune system mistakenly targets the thyroid gland, leading to chronic inflammation and damage. Antibodies play a crucial role in this process, Anti-Thyroid Peroxidase (TPO) Antibodies: Target an enzyme called thyroid peroxidase, which helps synthesise thyroid hormones. They are a hallmark of Hashimoto's thyroiditis and are frequently elevated in affected individuals. Anti-Thyroglobulin(Tg) Antibodies: Thyroglobulin is a protein involved in thyroid hormone production. Antibodies against thyroglobulin can disrupt hormone synthesis and contribute to thyroid gland damage. These antibodies and other immune cells contribute to the characteristic features of Hashimoto's thyroiditis, including thyroid gland enlargement, decreased thyroid hormone production, and symptoms of hypothyroidism. Hypoparathyroidism (Option A) is a condition where there is an underproduction of parathyroid hormone (PTH), leading to low blood calcium levels. It involves low PTH levels and affects calcium balance, but it is not related to thyroid hormone levels. Pituitary Adenoma (Option B) is a benign tumour of the pituitary gland that can affect its ability to produce hormones, including TSH. It can cause secondary hypothyroidism by not secreting enough TSH, but the given scenario is suggestive of primary hypothyroidism, not secondary (also called central hypothyroidism: Low TSH, T3, and T4 levels ). Grave's disease (Option C) is an autoimmune disorder that causes hyperthyroidism, which leads to elevated T4 and suppressed TSH , not low T4 and high TSH. Therefore, this is the opposite of what is presented in the question. Reference: Harrison’s principle of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 2934. Sabiston, Text Book of Surgery, 21st Edition, Pages 884, 886.

questions.question: A 40-year-old woman presents with complaints of swelling of the right breast over the past 15 days. On examination, there was a local rise in temperature, and the lump was mobile over the chest wall. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Inflammatory carcinoma Explanation: The presentation of the patient, along with redness and swelling of the right breast with a mobile lump, is suggestive of Inflammatory breast carcinoma. It is a rare but aggressive form of breast cancer characterised by pain, redness, swelling , and warmth of the breast. In I nflammatory breast carcinoma, edematous skin is tethered to the breast by Cooper ligaments and mimics orange peel or peau d’orange. Microscopy shows: No inflammation is present. Diffuse lymphovascular space plugging with carcinoma cells in dermal lymphatics. The presentation can be confused with a breast infection, leading to delayed diagnosis. The stage of Inflammatory Breast Cancer (IBC) is always T4d, which corresponds to at least stage III breast cancer. This indicates locally advanced disease with a poor prognosis, though it may be stage IV if distant metastases are present. Giant fibroadenoma (Option B) is a benign breast tumour that can grow large but is usually firm and mobile . It is not associated with warmth in the breast and is unlikely to cause signs of inflammation, as seen in inflammatory carcinoma. Phyllodes tumours (Option C), also called cystosarcoma phyllodes are stromal tumours developing from the connective tissue of the breast. Most of them are benign, but a small number can be borderline or malignant. They do not generally cause the redness and skin changes seen in inflammatory breast cancer. Galactocele (Option D) is a benign lump, which is a milk retention cyst, and it usually occurs in lactating women. It presents as a moderately firm, painless mass that may gradually or rapidly enlarge, with size fluctuations throughout the day. While they are generally painless and non-inflammatory, complications can occasionally lead to infection.

questions.question: Which of the following nerves is least injured during thyroid surgery?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Marginal mandibular nerve Explanation: The marginal mandibular nerve innervates the muscles of the lower lip and is the least at risk during thyroid surgery. It is not directly involved or at risk during thyroid surgery, as it is not in close proximity to the thyroid gland. Complications of Thyroidectomy Hemorrhage Bleeding from muscular arteries or slippage of ligature from superior thyroid vessels. Complication: Tension hematom a causing respiratory distress. Management: Immediate re-operation, open sutures, control bleeding, drain hematoma, and close the wound. Respiratory Obstruction Primary Cause: Laryngeal edema from extubation injury. (Most Common Complication) Other Causes: RLN palsy and tension hematoma. Nerve Injury Commonly Injured Nerve: External branch of the superior laryngeal nerve. Other Injuries: RLN Injury causing palsy and Cervical sympathetic trunk causing Horner's syndrome. (Options A & B ruled out) Parathyroid Insufficiency Ligating the inferior thyroid artery away from the thyroid leads to parathyroid vascular infarction. Causes hypocalcemia (low calcium levels) presenting 2–5 days post-surgery. Thyroid Insufficiency Total thyroidectomy leads to hypothyroidism and requires lifelong levothyroxine replacement. Thyrotoxic Crisis Inadequate preoperative preparation in hyperthyroid patients leads to the release of thyroid hormones during surgery. The external laryngeal nerve (Option C) is a branch of the superior laryngeal nerve that innervates the cricothyroid muscle, and it can be injured during thyroidectomy. Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page 865

questions.question: Which of the following is true about the flap given in the image?

options.A: Pedicled TRAM based on superior epigastric artery
options.B: Free TRAM based on superior and inferior epigastric artery
options.C: DIEP based on deep inferior epigastric artery
options.D: Lower abdominal fat-based inferior epigastric vessels

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) DIEP based on deep inferior epigastric artery Explanation: The flap given is DIEP (Deep Inferior Epigastric Perforator Flap), which involves harvesting tissue from the lower abdomen without taking the muscle. The flap relies on the deep inferior epigastric artery for blood supply, making it a muscle-sparing option for breast reconstruction or other soft tissue reconstructions. It is the best flap for breast reconstruction as there is no risk of hernia and muscle weakness. Breast Reconstruction Flaps Flaps Clinical Correlation Transverse Rectus Abdominis Muscle Flap (TRAM) Free flap involves using tissue from the abdomen, including both skin and muscle (Option A ruled out) Most commonly used flap but not the best flap It is based on inferior epigastric vessels Disadvantage: causes weakness in infra umbilical region Deep Inferior Epigastric Artery Perforator flap (DIEP) Flap which uses skin and fat from lower abdomen, but spares abdominal muscles Best flap for breast reconstruction as there is no risk of hernia and muscle weakness Latissimus Dorsi Flap Flap, which uses Latissimus dorsi muscle, skin and fat It is a type of subcutaneous flap based on thoracodorsal vessels. Pedicled TRAM based on the superior epigastric artery (Option A): A pedicled TRAM flap involves using the skin, muscle, fat and blood vessels, but the image does not depict a Pedicled TRAM flap ; the image actually shows a DIEP flap. Lower abdominal fat-based inferior epigastric vessels (Option D) The image does not depict lower abdominal fat based on inferior epigastric vessels; the image actually shows a DIEP flap.

questions.question: A 15-year-old boy undergoes bilateral adrenalectomy for phaeochromocytoma. On the third postoperative day, the boy feels lethargic and tired. Blood pressure is 80/60 mm Hg; there is no sign of bleeding. What could be the cause of this?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Addisonian crisis Explanation: The most likely cause of the patient's lethargy , fatigue , and hypotension (with no sign of bleeding) is an Addisonian crisis (also known as an adrenal crisis ) due to adrenal insufficiency after bilateral adrenalectomy . It occurs when there is a sudden, severe deficiency of cortisol and aldosterone . It leads to hypotension , electrolyte imbalances , and symptoms like lethargy and fatigue . It is managed by IV hydrocortisone. SIADH (Option B) results in hyponatremia due to excessive ADH secretion, but it does not explain the low blood pressure and fatigue in this patient, as the Addisonian crisis does. Diabetes insipidus (Option C) involves a deficiency of ADH or kidney resistance to it, leading to excessive urination and thirst . It would not typically present with the hypotension and lethargy seen in this patient. Cerebral salt wasting disease (Option D) can potentially cause increased urinary loss of sodium, hyponatremia and hypovolemia due to CNS conditions, while adrenal crisis shows low sodium alongside other symptoms related to low cortisol and aldosterone levels, requiring immediate hormone replacement therapy. Reference: Davidson's Principles and Practice of Medicine, 24th Edition, Pages 672-673

questions.question: What kind of thyroid cancer is frequently linked to prior radiation exposure, elevated RET/PTC rearrangements, and BRAF mutations?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Papillary carcinoma Explanation: Papillary thyroid carcinoma (PTC) is the most common type of thyroid cancer and is frequently linked to prior radiation exposure . It is also associated with RET/PTC rearrangements and BRAF mutations , both of which are genetic alterations commonly found in this type of cancer. Papillary (Option B) Follicular (Option A ruled out) Medullary (Option D ruled out) Anaplastic (Option C ruled out) Origin Follicular cells Follicular cells Para follicular cells Follicular cells Risk factors Radiation Thyroglossal cyst Hashimoto’s thyroiditis Iodine deficiency Multinodular goitre - - Genetics BRAF, RET-PTC PAX-8,/PPAR-1, PTEN, P-53, RAS RET, MEN II P53 Clinical Manifestations Seen in the 3rd to 4th decade. Midline swelling in the anterior part of the neck Occasionally, lateral aberrant thyroid is seen. Seen in the 5th to 6th decade. A sudden increase in the size of the swelling Minimal or no pain Raised calcitonin. History of diarrhoea Family history of pheochromocytoma or hyperparathyroidism Metastasis Lymphatic Hematogenous Both Both and Direct invasion. Histopathology Optically clear nuclei (Orphan Annie eye nuclei) Dystrophic calcification (Psammoma bodies) Follicles (multiple foci are seen) Amyloid deposition Highly pleomorphic cells, spindle cells, giant cells, often areas of necrosis and mitotic figures.

questions.question: Best way to localise extra-adrenal pheochromocytoma:
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Nucleotide scan Explanation: The best method to localise extra-adrenal pheochromocytomas is through a Nucleotide scan (such as MIBG or PET scan), which allows for accurate identification of the tumour's location. MIBG is a radiopharmaceutical that is selectively absorbed by neuroendocrine tumours, such as pheochromocytomas. When radioactive iodine-labelled MIBG is administered intravenously, the tumour cells take it up due to their affinity for norepinephrine. Once the MIBG is taken up by the tumour, a whole-body scan is performed using a gamma camera , allowing for the precise localization of pheochromocytomas, including extra-adrenal tumours . X-ray (Option A) is not suitable for visualising soft tissue tumours like pheochromocytomas or detecting abnormal growths. It is better suited for visualising bones or detecting larger, more obvious structural abnormalities. VMA excretion (Option C) is a metabolite of catecholamines and can be measured in urine to help diagnose pheochromocytoma . However, while increased VMA (Vanillyl mandelic acid) excretion is suggestive of pheochromocytoma, it does not help localise the tumor . Clinical examination (Option D) can reveal signs and symptoms of pheochromocytoma, but it is not reliable for localising an extra-adrenal pheochromocytoma. Symptoms like hypertension, sweating, and tachycardia suggest the presence of pheochromocytoma, but further imaging studies (like the nucleotide scan) are required for accurate localisation. Reference: Grainger and Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology, 7th Edition, Page 950. Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Pages 900, 901.

questions.question: Grey-Turner's sign is seen in:
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Acute pancreatitis Explanation: Grey-Turner's sign refers to bluish discolouration or bruising of the flanks (the sides of the abdomen), which can be seen in severe acute pancreatitis . It is a sign of retroperitoneal hemorrhage , which occurs when pancreatic inflammation spreads from the anterior pararenal space to the lateral edge of the quadratus lumborum muscle, causing bruising on the flanks. Acute appendicitis (Option A) generally presents with right lower abdominal pain, fever, and nausea. It does not usually cause retroperitoneal haemorrhage or bruising, so Grey-Turner's sign is not associated with it. Acute cholecystitis (Option C) involves inflammation of the gallbladder, usually causing right upper quadrant pain. While it may cause jaundice or tenderness, Grey-Turner's sign is not typically seen. Acute hepatitis (Option D) involves liver inflammation, often caused by viral infections or drug-induced liver injury, which can cause jaundice, but Grey-Turner's sign is not characteristic of hepatitis. Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 1055. NIH Link .

questions.question: A 50-year-old woman after thyroidectomy comes to you for a 2 nd opinion for further treatment of papillary thyroid cancer. What would you recommend for this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Radioiodine scan Explanation: After thyroidectomy for papillary thyroid cancer, a radioiodine scan (I-131) is recommended to detect any remaining thyroid tissue or metastasis, as papillary thyroid cancer is often Radioactive Iodine (RAI) -avid (capable of absorbing and concentrating radioactive iodine). Roles: Remnant Ablation: Destruction of any remaining benign thyroid tissue following a total or subtotal thyroidectomy. Adjuvant Therapy: Additional treatment post-surgery to reduce the risk of cancer recurrence. Treatment of Known Disease: Targeting and destroying residual cancer cells or recurrent structural or biochemical disease. Radioactive Iodine Ablation (RAI): Isotope Used : Iodine-131 (Half-Life: 8 Days) Emission: Beta Rays : 90% of emissions; targeted treatment of the thyroid gland while sparing surrounding tissues. Gamma Rays: 10% of emissions; used for imaging and also responsible for side effects. Applications: Primarily for Differentiated Thyroid Cancer (DTC) like Papillary Thyroid Carcinoma (PTC) and Follicular Thyroid Carcinoma (FTC). Side Effects : (Dose-Dependent): Sialadenitis, nasolacrimal duct obstruction, transient swelling, infertility, secondary malignancies (e.g., leukemia) Indications Contraindications Differentiated thyroid cancers E.g., Papillary thyroid carcinoma Follicular thyroid carcinoma Hurthle cell carcinoma Tumor size >2cm One or more risk factors Obvious extrathyroidal extension >45 years of age Lymph node and distant metastasis Poorly differentiated thyroid cancers E.g., Medullary thyroid carcinoma Anaplastic thyroid carcinoma Pregnancy & Breastfeeding (Absolute contraindications) Vomiting & Diarrhea (Relative contraindications) Radiotherapy (Option A) is not the standard follow-up after thyroidectomy for papillary thyroid cancer (PTC). RAI therapy is preferred as it targets thyroid tissue, while radiotherapy is reserved for advanced cases or metastasis. RAI is more effective than radiotherapy for treating remaining thyroid cells or metastasis. Chemotherapy (Option B): Papillary thyroid cancer (PTC) is not treated with chemotherapy, as it doesn't respond well. RAI is the standard treatment, while chemotherapy is used for more aggressive cancers like anaplastic thyroid cancer. Wait and watch (Option D) approach may be used in low-risk cases of papillary thyroid cancer (PTC) if the tumor is small, localized, and has been fully removed. However, after thyroidectomy, a radioiodine scan (RAI) is typically done to check for remaining tissue or metastases, even in low-risk cases. Reference: Sabiston’s Textbook of Surgery , 21st Edition, Page 905. SRB’s Manual of Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 476. Radioactive Iodine Therapy for Thyroid Malignancies - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf

questions.question: A 34-year-old male presents with a serum calcium level of 12.8 mg/dL (normal range: 8.5–10.25 mg/dL) along with elevated parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels. Ultrasound imaging reveals a 1.5 x 1.5 cm mass in the right lower lobe of the thyroid gland. Which of the following statements is correct regarding this condition?

options.A: MIBI followed by focussed parathyroidectomy to be done
options.B: Normal DEXA scan rules out the need for surgery
options.C: Only observation, no need for surgery
options.D: Creatinine clearance > 80 ml/min mandates the surgery

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) MIBI followed by focussed parathyroidectomy to be done Explanation: MIBI scan followed by focused parathyroidectomy is the recommended course of action for this patient. This scenario suggests primary hyperparathyroidism, likely due to a parathyroid adenoma, given the elevated calcium and PTH levels, along with the thyroid mass that could be related to a parathyroid lesion. Sestamibi scan is a type of nuclear medicine-based study that is most accurate for parathyroid lesion localisation. Indications of parathyroidectomy include: (Option C ruled out) Severe symptoms Young age Markedly reduced bone density Serum calcium more than 11mg% Urinary calculi Neuromuscular symptoms Urinary calcium more than 400mg/24 hour Normal DEXA scan rules out the need for surgery (Option B) is not true because even if bone density is normal, elevated calcium and PTH levels indicate that the parathyroid adenoma should be addressed surgically. Creatinine clearance > 80 ml/min mandates the surgery (Option D) : Surgical intervention is primarily indicated based on the diagnosis of primary hyperparathyroidism and the presence of complications or symptoms, not just creatinine clearance. Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Pages 876, 879

questions.question: Which of the following is not a component of MEN2B syndrome?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Parathyroid hyperplasia Explanation: Parathyroid hyperplasia is associated with MEN2A , not MEN2B. MEN is a group of genetic syndromes ( Autosomal Dominant ) characterised by the development of tumours in multiple endocrine glands. Diagnostic criteria for MEN is Clinical features of 2 or more associated tumours. Notable Family history Confirmation by genetic analysis. MEN2B is also called as MEN type 3. Types of Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia MEN Type I MEN Type II MEN Type III MEN Type IV Cause Defect of chromosome 11q13 causing MEN 1 gene mutation Also called Wermer’s syndrome Defect of chr.10 leading to mutation of RET gene Also called Sipple’s syndrome Also called MEN II B , it is a variant of Type 2 MEN Defect of chr.12 causing CDKN1B gene Tumors Included Parathyroid adenoma (most common) It presents with primary hyperparathyroidism ( ↑ PTH and ↑ Ca) All the four glands can be included. Rx: Total/subtotal parathyroid resection Parathyroid adenoma ( most common, and calcium can be normal) Medullary carcinoma thyroid ( most common) (Option A ruled out) Parathyroid adenoma ( Presents as hypercalcemia) Pancreatic adenoma Presents as Gastrinoma or Zollinger-Ellison syndrome This leads to peptic ulcer disease in the duodenum, which is the leading cause of death in this type. Pheochromocytoma . Pheochromocytoma (Most important criterion for both MEN 2 and MEN 3): Presents with elevated blood pressure. Pituitary adenoma: Prolactinoma Pituitary adenoma: Prolactinoma, causing amenorrhea and Infertility Medullary thyroid carcinoma Calcitonin is the tumor marker present Cold nodules are seen on the thyroid scan Metastasis can be traced with PET scan Visible neck mass, causing dysphagia Rx - Prophylactic thyroidectomy Reproductive tract tumors Testicular tumours Neuroendocrine tumor (Cervix) Associated conditions Angio I broma Collagenoma Adrenocortical tumor Carcinoid tumors/Argenta I noma Pheochromocytoma (only in 1%) Congenital aganglionosis, Hirschsprung disease Marfanoid habitus (Option C ruled out) Medullated corneal nerve I bers Mucosal neuromas (Option B ruled out) Megacolon and Multiple diverticulae Occasionally with Renal tumour Adrenal tumour Reference: Harrison’s Principle of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Pages 2983 - 2990 Davidson’s Principles and Practice of Medicine, 24th Edition, Pages 868, 869

questions.question: A 20-year-old male presents with occasional palpitations, high blood pressure, and headache. He is diagnosed with pheochromocytoma. What is the preferred initial investigation?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) 24 hours urine metanephrines Explanation: The preferred initial investigation in a patient suspected of having pheochromocytoma is a 24-hour urine collection for metanephrines , as it is a sensitive and specific test for detecting catecholamine-secreting tumours. Pheochromocytoma Definition A catecholamine-secreting tumour that arises from the chromaffin cells of the abdominal sympathetic chain/ adrenal medulla Co-exist with neurofibromatosis, VHL syndrome, MEN syndrome Clinical features Classical triad: Headache (most common), profuse sweating, palpitation and tachycardia Hypertension (sustained or intermittent) Anxiety, panic attacks Hyperglycemia and Hypercalcemia Pallor (due to alpha-1 mediated vasoconstriction) Polyuria and polydipsia Orthostatic hypotension Dilated cardiomyopathy Erythrocytosis Constipation Abdominal pain Weakness Weight Loss The rule of 10 10% are bilateral 10% are extra-adrenal 10% are malignant 25-33% are inherited Symptomatic patients do not follow the Rule of 10’s Diagnosis Measurement of the plasma fractionated metanephrines is the most sensitive screening test; hence, the initial investigation is preferred. Increase 24 hour urinary VMA(Vanillyl mandelic acid) and metanephrines (Option D) MRI is the investigation of choice. (Option B ruled out) Biopsy and CT contrast scans are contraindicated in order to avoid hypertensive crises Treatment Adrenalectomy is the treatment of choice Size<5cm- Laparoscopic adrenalectomy Preop Alpha-blockers should be given Mitotane should be started as adjuvant or palliative treatment USG-abdomen (Option A) may sometimes be used to assess abdominal masses, it is not the preferred initial investigation for pheochromocytoma, as it may not detect smaller tumours or those located in less accessible areas, such as the adrenal glands or retroperitoneal space. MIBG (Option C) is specialised imaging studies used for further evaluation, especially in metastatic or multifocal cases, and are not used for initial biochemical confirmation after plasma testing. Reference: Sabiston’s Text Book of Surgery, 21st Edition, Page 987 OP Ghai Essentials of Pediatrics, 10th Edition, Pages 545, 546

questions.question: Which is the most lethal nerve injury during thyroid surgery?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) B/L RLN (complete) Explanation: The recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN) is a crucial structure in thyroid surgery because it innervates the laryngeal muscles , which control vocal cord function. Bilateral complete injury to the RLN is the most lethal nerve injury during thyroid surgery as it can cause paralysis of both vocal cords , leading to stridor, voice changes, breathing difficulties, and, in severe cases, airway obstruction. Unilateral injury is generally less dangerous than bilateral injury because the contralateral vocal cord can compensate to a significant degree. (Options A & C ruled out) The individual may experience hoarseness or aspiration of fluids through the glottis. Partial injury typically does not lead to significant airway compromise. (Option B ruled out) Reference: Reference: Dhingra's Diseases Of Ear, Nose And Throat, & Head and Neck Surgery, 8th Edition, Page 350 Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 865

questions.question: Which of the following is the most common cause of bloody nipple discharge?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Intraductal papilloma Explanation: Intraductal papilloma: A benign tumor that forms in a milk duct in the breast. It is the most common cause of bloody nipple discharge. Symptoms : The most common cause of Nipple discharge (often clear or bloody), a palpable lump near the nipple. Causes : Age (35-55 years) Longtime exposure to estrogen Family history of breast cancer Diagnosis : Clinical breast examination Imaging: Mammography and ultrasound Biopsy to rule out malignancy. Treatment : Surgical removal of the papilloma and the affected duct and monitoring for any signs of recurrence. Nipple Discharge Type of Nipple Discharge Causes Bloody Intraductal Papilloma (Most Common) Breast Carcinoma Duct Ectasia Serous Fibrocystic Disease (Most Common) Breast Carcinoma Duct Ectasia Greenish/Blackish Duct Ectasia Milk (Galactorrhea) Physiological (e.g., Pregnancy, Lactation) Hyperprolactinemia (e.g., Pituitary Adenoma, Hypothyroidism) Medications (e.g., Antipsychotics, Antidepressants, Oral Contraceptives) Purulent Breast Abscess Mastitis Breast cancer (Option A): Both ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) and invasive ductal carcinoma can present with bloody discharge. However, this is not the most common cause as compared to intraductal papilloma. Fibroadenoma (Option B): Benign breast tumors that are most common in young women. They are usually painless, firm, and mobile lumps within the breast. Fibroadenomas do not typically cause bloody nipple discharge Duct ectasia (Option D): Inflammation and dilation of the ducts, which can sometimes cause bloody discharge. However, this is not the most common cause as compared to intraductal papilloma. Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 924. SRB's Manual of Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 556.

questions.question: A 23-year-old female visited the clinician with a solitary thyroid nodule and was advised for thyroid function tests where Tsh level is 27.3mU/L, T3 is 1.24 ng/ml, and T4 is 4.87 microgram/ml. Which of the following manifestations is true regarding the condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Weight gain Explanation: The patient’s thyroid function tests show elevated TSH with normal T3 and T4 levels, indicating primary hypothyroidism. Weight Gain is consistent with hypothyroidism due to reduced metabolic rate. Heat Intolerance ( Option A ) , Tachycardia ( Option B ), and Diarrhea ( Option C ) are more common in hyperthyroidism , not hypothyroidism. Hypothyroidism Hyperthyroidism Decreased metabolic rate Increased metabolic rate Weight gain, puffiness, dry skin Weight loss Decreased appetite Increased appetite Bradycardia Tachycardia Cold intolerance Heat intolerance Constipation Diarrhea Menorrhagia Amenorrhea, infertility Cardiomegaly, pericardial effusion. Cardiovascular complications such as atrial fibrillation, cardiomyopathy, and Congestive heart failure. Altered mental status, coma - Reference: Sabiston’s Textbook of Surgery, 21st Edition, Pages 884, 886

questions.question: A 40-year-old female presents with an irregular 5 x 6 cm mass in the right breast. Histopathological examination reveals findings consistent with which of the following diagnoses?
questions.explanation: borderline, or malignant. It is characterized by a leaf-like (phyllodes) pattern on histopathology, with stromal overgrowth and an irregular, well-defined mass. The description of a 5 x 6 cm irregular mass in a middle-aged woman aligns with a phyllodes tumor, making this the correct diagnosis. Incorrect Options: Option B - Fibroadenoma: This is a common benign breast tumor, typically presenting as a well-circumscribed, mobile mass in younger women. Histologically, it consists of both glandular and stromal components, but lacks the stromal overgrowth seen in phyllodes tumors. The irregularity and size described here are less characteristic of a fibroadenoma. Option C - Mastitis : This refers to an infection of the breast tissue, often associated with breastfeeding. It typically presents with pain, redness, and swelling, rather than a well-defined mass. Histologically, it shows inflammatory changes rather than a tumor pattern, making it an unlikely diagnosis in this case. Option D - Grade 2 breast tumor : This term typically refers to an invasive ductal carcinoma of intermediate grade. While it can present as a mass, the histopathological description would focus on invasive cancer cells, not the leaf-like architecture described. This option does not fit the histopathological features expected in this scenario.

questions.question: A patient presents to the outpatient department with an ulcerated breast tumor and liver metastasis. What is the appropriate management?
questions.explanation: distant metastases (such as liver metastasis), the primary goal is to downstage the disease and reduce the tumor burden before considering surgical intervention. Neoadjuvant chemotherapy (chemotherapy given before surgery) helps shrink the tumor and potentially the metastatic sites, making subsequent surgery more feasible. In some cases, surgery may be considered after effective systemic treatment has been achieved, depending on the response to chemotherapy and the overall treatment plan. Incorrect Options: Option A - Simple mastectomy : This procedure involves the removal of the entire breast but does not address regional lymph nodes or distant metastases. It is not appropriate for stage 4 breast cancer with liver metastasis, as the disease has spread beyond the breast and regional nodes. Option B - Modified Radical Mastectomy (MRM): This involves the removal of the breast along with the axillary lymph nodes. While it is a more extensive surgery compared to a simple mastectomy, it is still not sufficient for stage 4 breast cancer with distant metastasis. This approach does not address the metastatic disease in the liver. Option C - Radical mastectomy : This is an extensive surgical procedure that involves removal of the breast, axillary lymph nodes, and underlying chest muscles. Like the previous options, it is not appropriate for stage 4 breast cancer with liver metastasis, as the cancer has already spread beyond the breast and regional lymph nodes. Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 934,935

questions.question: A female presented with 1x 1 cm thyroid swelling. What is next best step in management?
questions.explanation: thyroid function, which involves measuring TSH and T4 levels. This approach helps determine whether the thyroid gland is functioning normally or if there are abnormalities, such as hyperthyroidism or hypothyroidism, that could influence the management plan for the thyroid nodule. This information is crucial for deciding whether additional diagnostic procedures, such as a thyroid ultrasound or fine needle aspiration Incorrect Options: Option A - I-131 (Radioactive Iodine Therapy): I-131 is used primarily for treating hyperthyroidism or thyroid cancer, not for initial evaluation of a thyroid swelling. It is not appropriate for the initial assessment of a thyroid nodule. Option B - TSH (Thyroid-Stimulating Hormone) Test: TSH is a crucial initial test for evaluating thyroid function. It helps determine if the thyroid is underactive (hypothyroidism) or overactive (hyperthyroidism). However, TSH alone does not provide information about thyroid hormone levels or nodule characteristics, which are also important. Option D - T3 (Triiodothyronine) and T4 (Thyroxine) Test: T3 and T4 levels measure thyroid hormone levels, but TSH is more useful for assessing overall thyroid function. T3 levels are less commonly measured unless specifically indicated, as TSH and T4 are typically sufficient for initial evaluation. Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 851, 858

questions.question: A patient presents with a swelling in the thyroid region that moves with deglutination and protrusion of the tongue. The swelling has ruptured, resulting in pus discharge. What is the preferred treatment?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Sistrunk procedure Explanation: The clinical presentation and image classically suggest a Thyroglossal cyst, which is managed by removing the cyst along with the tract up to the base of the tongue and part of the hyoid bone (SISTRUNK Procedure) Thyroglossal Cyst: It is a congenital neck mass resulting from the persistence of the thyroglossal duct, an embryological structure. It can also be present in adulthood. The cyst represents a remnant of this duct and can be found anywhere along the midline from the base of the tongue to the thyroid isthmus. It presents as midline swelling that moves with deglutition and protrusion of the tongue. Most Common Site: Subhyoid (can also be seen on the floor of the mouth, Suprahyoid, near thyroid cartilage and foramen caecum) Treatment: Sistrunk Procedure : Complete surgical excision of the cyst and its tract up to the base of the tongue, as well as a portion of the hyoid bone, to prevent recurrence. Incision and drainage (Option C) are never done as they lead to the formation of a Thyroglossal fistula. (It also forms if an inflamed cyst ruptures.)—Always Acquired. Long-standing thyroglossal cyst - - - > Risk of developing into Papillary thyroid carcinoma. Antibiotics (Option B) might be used as adjunctive therapy to treat infection, but they are not the definitive treatment.

questions.question: Which of the following is not an indication for parathyroidectomy in a patient with primary hyperparathyroidism?

options.A: Serum calcium > 1 mg/dL above the upper limit of normal

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Creatinine clearance < 90 mL/min Explanation: Creatinine clearance < 90 mL/min is not an indication for parathyroidectomy. Indications for Parathyroidectomy: Serum calcium > 0.25 mmol/L (1.0 mg/dL) above the upper limit of normal. (Option A) Bone Mineral Density (BMD) by DEXA: T-score ≤ -2.5 at the lumbar spine, total hip, femoral neck, or distal one-third of radius. Vertebral fracture. Creatinine clearance < 60 mL/min. 24-hour urinary calcium > 10 mmol/dL (>400 mg/day) (Option B) or increased risk of stone formation Age < 50 years (Option C) Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 879

questions.question: A middle-aged man with a history of renal calculi presents with bone pain and abdominal cramps. X-ray shows subperiosteal resorption of the 2nd and 3rd metacarpals and phalanges. Serum calcium and PTH are raised, and phosphate levels are decreased. Which of the following investigations will help localise the pathology?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) 99Tc radiolabelled sestamibi scan Explanation: This patient's presentation is highly suggestive of primary hyperparathyroidism . The most common cause of primary hyperparathyroidism is a solitary parathyroid adenoma . The characteristic findings of subperiosteal resorption on X-ray, along with elevated calcium and PTH levels and low phosphate , point towards this diagnosis. To localise the pathology (typically a parathyroid adenoma), the most appropriate imaging test is a 99Tc radiolabelled sestamibi scan . Sestamibi scan is a type of nuclear medicine-based study that is most accurate for parathyroid lesion localisation. It is safe and reproducible . It has a sensitivity and specificity similar to ultrasound but may detect glands in ectopic positions better. Sestamibi accumulates in the mitochondria, and henc,e the rates at which it washes out differ as per the number of mitochondria in different tissues. Parathyroid adenoma is rich in oxyphilic cells with a high

questions.question: A patient presents with polyuria, polydipsia, lethargy, and abdominal pain. She also has a history of mood disorders and recurrent kidney stones. Which of the following investigations would not be useful in arriving at the diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Angiography of renal arteries Explanation: The patient’s symptoms, including polyuria , polydipsia , lethargy , abdominal pain , and a history of recurrent kidney stones , strongly suggest a diagnosis of primary hyperparathyroidism , which can result in hypercalcemia . The most likely cause of primary hyperparathyroidism is a parathyroid adenoma. Angiography of renal arteries is typically used to evaluate the renal vasculature in cases of renal artery stenosis or other vascular abnormalities. However, it does not provide useful information for diagnosing primary hyperparathyroidism, which is the most likely diagnosis in this patient. Incorrect Options: Nuclear sestamibi scan (Option A) is used to identify parathyroid adenomas . It is a key investigation in the diagnosis of primary hyperparathyroidism , especially in localising the adenoma. USG neck (Option B) can also help in visualising parathyroid glands and is commonly used for parathyroid adenomas . Dual energy radiographic absorptiometry (DEXA) (Option C) is a test used to assess bone density and is often ordered to evaluate for osteoporosis , which is common in primary hyperparathyroidism due to bone resorption from elevated calcium. Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 877, 878 SRB's Manual of Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 491 https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4607146/

questions.question: What is the preferred treatment for a benign tumour of the superficial parathyroid gland?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Surgical resection Explanation: The preferred treatment for a benign tumour of the superficial parathyroid gland is surgical resection, which involves removing the tumour to avoid complications. Since benign parathyroid tumours (often referred to as adenomas) can lead to conditions like hypercalcemia, surgery is usually the most effective and curative treatment. The main modality of treatment is as follows: Indications of parathyroidectomy: Severe symptoms Young age Markedly reduced bone density Serum calcium more than 11mg% Urinary calculi Neuromuscular symptoms Urinary calcium more than 400mg/24 hours Indications of surgery in an asymptomatic case are: Serum calcium 0.25 mmol/L (1.0 mg/dL) above the upper limit of normal Bone mineral density (BMD) by DEXA; T score –2.5 at lumbar spine, total hip, femoral neck, or distal one-third of radius Vertebral fracture Creatinine clearance <60 mL/min 24-hour urinary calcium >10 mmol/dL (>400 mg/day) or increased risk of stone formation by risk analysis Age <50 years When medical therapy is not possible Miami Protocol: An intraoperative PTH is measured If it has reduced by more than 50% than the preoperative value, it indicates surgical removal. Casanova test: It is to differentiate the recurrence site after Removal of all 4 Parathyroid gland and auto transplant of it. PTH measurements are taken from the neck vein & brachial vessel. A positive Casanova test is if 20 times higher concentration in the brachial vessel Contraindications of surgery: Absolute contraindication: familial hypercalciuric hypercalcemia Here, elevated calcium and PTH level but 24 hr urinary calcium and calcium to creatinine clearance are low. Parathyroidectomy does not cure hypercalcemia due to FHH syndrome. Relative contraindications: Controlateral recurrent laryngeal nerve injury. Vocal cord dysfunction.

questions.question: ER positivity is used as which of the following in the context of breast carcinoma?
questions.explanation: present in the breast and tumor tissue. It is an important indicator of prognosis of carcinoma breast. If the value is more than 10 units (f/mols) per n gram of tissue it is called ER +ve status. ER positivity is common in postmenopausal women (60%) compared to premeno- pausal women (30%). If the value is less than 10 units per gram of tissue it is called ER-ve status. ER +ve status ER -ve status Prognosis is good. Hormone therapy including tamoxifen is more beneficial. Response to treatment is better. Prognosis is poor. Hormone therapy is not very beneficial (but used) as compared to ER +ve patients. Response to treatment is not good. Incorrect Options: Options A - Diagnostic marker: AFP, CA153, and CA199 are tumour markers used in the diagnosis of breast cancer. Option C - Surrogate molecular marker: Surrogate molecular marker, based on immunohistochemical markers identifies different subtypes of breast carcinoma. Option D - Treatment: Treatment is based on the TNM staging of breast cancer.

questions.question: Which of the following will not result in hoarseness of voice after a thyroid surgery?
questions.explanation: hoarseness of the voice. The external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve is closely related to the superior thyroid vessels. Hence, ligation of superior thyroid vessels is more likely to injure the external branch of superior laryngeal nerve. Incorrect Options: Option A - Dissecting/retracting strap muscles: Strap muscles are anterior to the thyroid lobes. Dissecting/retracting strap muscles could lead to injury of recurrent laryngeal nerves.
